title: Jeremiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 51 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 51.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:1, what will the LORD raise up against Babylon?
options: A destroying wind
A mighty army
A flood
A fire
questions.correctAnswer: A destroying wind
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:1 says the LORD will raise up a destroying wind against Babylon.

questions.question: Jeremiah 51:2 mentions 'fanners' sent to Babylon. What is their purpose?
options: To fan Babylon and empty her land
To bring peace to Babylon
To protect Babylon from enemies
To teach wisdom to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: To fan Babylon and empty her land
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:2 states that the LORD will send fanners to fan Babylon and empty her land.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 51:5 says Israel and Judah have been forsaken by God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:5 clearly states that Israel and Judah have not been forsaken by God.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:6 command the people to do regarding Babylon?
options: Flee out of the midst of Babylon
Build stronger walls
Pray for Babylon's peace
Trade with Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Flee out of the midst of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:6 commands everyone to flee out of Babylon to save their lives.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:7, what has Babylon been in the LORD's hand?
options: A golden cup
A mighty fortress
A burning fire
A strong tower
questions.correctAnswer: A golden cup
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:7 describes Babylon as a golden cup in the LORD's hand.

questions.question: Jeremiah 51:8 says Babylon is suddenly what?
options: Fallen and destroyed
Growing strong
Peaceful and prosperous
Protected by kings
questions.correctAnswer: Fallen and destroyed
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:8 states that Babylon is suddenly fallen and destroyed.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 51:11 mentions the spirit of the kings of the Medes being raised by the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:11 confirms that the LORD raised up the spirit of the kings of the Medes against Babylon.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 51:14, the LORD says He will fill Babylon with men as many as what?
options: Caterpillars
Stars in the sky
Grains of sand
Leaves on trees
questions.correctAnswer: Caterpillars
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:14 says the LORD will fill Babylon with men as with caterpillars.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:15, what has the LORD done by His power and wisdom?
options: Made the earth and established the world
Destroyed Babylon
Raised up the kings of the Medes
Built the temple in Zion
questions.correctAnswer: Made the earth and established the world
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:15 states that the LORD made the earth by His power and established the world by His wisdom.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Jeremiah 51:17: 'Every man is brutish by his ______; every founder is confounded by the graven image.'
options: knowledge
strength
wisdom
faith
questions.correctAnswer: knowledge
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:17 says every man is brutish by his knowledge.

questions.question: Jeremiah 51:20 describes Israel as what to the LORD?
options: My battle axe and weapons of war
My chosen people
My servants forever
My holy city
questions.correctAnswer: My battle axe and weapons of war
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:20 calls Israel the LORD's battle axe and weapons of war.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:25, God compares Babylon to what kind of mountain?
options: A destroying mountain
A peaceful mountain
A hidden mountain
A holy mountain
questions.correctAnswer: A destroying mountain
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:25 refers to Babylon as a destroying mountain which destroys all the earth.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 51:30 says the mighty men of Babylon remained strong and victorious in their fight.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:30 states the mighty men of Babylon have failed and become as women, their might has failed.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:44 say will happen to Bel in Babylon?
options: He will be punished and what he swallowed will be brought out
He will be exalted above all gods
He will protect Babylon
He will gather the nations together
questions.correctAnswer: He will be punished and what he swallowed will be brought out
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:44 declares the LORD will punish Bel and bring forth out of his mouth what he swallowed.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:63, what is Seraiah instructed to do after reading the book in Babylon?
options: Bind a stone to it and cast it into the midst of Euphrates
Hide the book in the temple
Burn the book
Take the book back to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Bind a stone to it and cast it into the midst of Euphrates
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:63 instructs Seraiah to bind a stone to the book and cast it into the Euphrates river.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 51 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is anxious about the judgment coming upon Babylon. Based on Jeremiah 51, what biblical truth about God's justice and mercy would you share?
options: God has not forsaken Israel and Judah despite their sins and will bring justice on Babylon.
God ignores the sins of nations until they repent fully.
God only punishes individuals, not nations.
God punishes Babylon without any reason or previous warning.
questions.correctAnswer: God has not forsaken Israel and Judah despite their sins and will bring justice on Babylon.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:5 reassures that Israel and Judah are not forsaken by God despite their sins. Verses 6, 24, and 56 show that God will bring vengeance upon Babylon for their evil deeds, demonstrating His justice and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51 teach us about trusting God's plan during times of judgment and destruction?
options: God's plan will be fulfilled and His purposes accomplished despite opposition.
God's plans can be easily thwarted by human strength.
God delays judgment indefinitely to give more time.
God punishes without any predetermined plan.
questions.correctAnswer: God's plan will be fulfilled and His purposes accomplished despite opposition.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:29 states that every purpose of the LORD will be performed against Babylon, emphasizing God's sovereignty. Verses 12 and 53 affirm that God both devises and executes His plans, regardless of human efforts.

questions.question: A believer is feeling weak and helpless in spiritual battles. According to Jeremiah 51, what encouragement about God's power and provision would you share?
options: God uses His people as weapons to break down opposition and will empower them.
Strength comes only from human effort and training.
Victory depends on numbers and political alliances.
Prayer is unnecessary in spiritual warfare.
questions.correctAnswer: God uses His people as weapons to break down opposition and will empower them.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:20-23 describes God calling His people 'battle axe and weapons of war' to destroy kingdoms and rulers. Verses 15-16 highlight God's wisdom and power in creation, assuring believers of His strength in their battles.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51 encourage believers to respond to temptation and trials related to worldly influences?
options: Flee from the midst of Babylon to save your soul and avoid iniquity.
Embrace worldly pleasures as a way to cope.
Ignore warnings and rely on self-strength.
Wait passively for deliverance without action.
questions.correctAnswer: Flee from the midst of Babylon to save your soul and avoid iniquity.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:6 and 45 urge God's people to flee Babylon to save themselves from her iniquity and the LORD's fierce anger. This teaches believers to actively avoid environments leading to temptation and sin.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51 teach about humility and contentment in light of Babylon's pride and destruction?
options: Babylon's pride led to its downfall; humility is essential to avoid such ruin.
Pride has no consequences in God's eyes.
Contentment means accumulating as much as possible.
Pride is a sign of God's favor.
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon's pride led to its downfall; humility is essential to avoid such ruin.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:9 notes Babylon's judgment reaching to the heavens due to her pride. Verses 3 and 53 warn against lifting oneself up. This underlines the biblical principle that pride leads to destruction, while humility brings preservation.

questions.question: How can believers apply the teaching of Jeremiah 51 about God's sovereignty in their work ethic and daily labor?
options: Recognize God as the creator and sustainer of all, working with integrity under His authority.
Work only for human recognition and reward.
Ignore God's role in daily life and work.
Avoid responsibility since God controls everything.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God as the creator and sustainer of all, working with integrity under His authority.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:15-16 states God made the earth by His power and established the world by His wisdom, showing His sovereignty over all work and creation. This calls believers to work diligently and honestly as servants of God.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with bitterness towards others who have wronged them. What biblical principle from Jeremiah 51 can help them respond with forgiveness?
options: Trust God to render justice and vengeance, leaving room for personal forgiveness.
Take vengeance personally to restore honor.
Hold grudges to protect oneself.
Ignore justice and pretend nothing happened.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to render justice and vengeance, leaving room for personal forgiveness.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:24 and 56 show that God will recompense Babylon for their evil deeds. Believers can learn to trust God's justice and focus on forgiveness and reconciliation rather than seeking personal revenge.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51 teach about the importance of spiritual vigilance and preparation in the life of a believer?
options: Set up standards, strengthen watches, and prepare ambushes as God commands to guard against spiritual attack.
Ignore spiritual dangers and live carelessly.
Rely solely on others for spiritual protection.
Avoid all conflict by isolating oneself.
questions.correctAnswer: Set up standards, strengthen watches, and prepare ambushes as God commands to guard against spiritual attack.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:12 commands to set up standards on Babylon's walls, make the watch strong, and prepare ambushes, illustrating the need for vigilance and preparation. This applies spiritually to believers guarding their faith.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by false teachings and idols in their community. What does Jeremiah 51 teach about the nature of idols and how should believers respond?
options: Idols are vanity and falsehood without breath; believers should reject them and trust the living God.
Idols have power and should be respected.
Idols are harmless decorations.
Idols can be used alongside true worship.
questions.correctAnswer: Idols are vanity and falsehood without breath; believers should reject them and trust the living God.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:17-18 describe idols as vain works of errors with no breath, destined to perish. Believers are called to reject idols and cling to the LORD of hosts, the living God.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51 encourage believers to maintain hope and perseverance during times of national or personal trial?
options: God will plead your cause and take vengeance for you, making dry the sea and springs of your enemies.
Give up hope and accept defeat.
Rely only on human strength to overcome trials.
Ignore God's promises and focus on present pain.
questions.correctAnswer: God will plead your cause and take vengeance for you, making dry the sea and springs of your enemies.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:36 promises God will plead the cause and bring vengeance, symbolized by drying the sea and springs, encouraging believers to persevere trusting God's deliverance.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51, what biblical principle can be drawn about evangelism and sharing the gospel in difficult times?
options: Proclaim the work of the LORD boldly, declaring His righteousness and judgment.
Remain silent to avoid conflict.
Only share the gospel when conditions are perfect.
Leave evangelism to others and focus on personal piety.
questions.correctAnswer: Proclaim the work of the LORD boldly, declaring His righteousness and judgment.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:10 encourages declaring in Zion the work of the LORD our God, highlighting the importance of boldly sharing God's righteousness and judgment even during difficult times.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 51 teaches that God's judgment on Babylon is final and desolation will last forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 26, 37, and 43 describe Babylon becoming desolate forever, without inhabitants, and a place of astonishment, confirming the finality of God's judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 51 encourages believers to fear rumors and be overwhelmed by them without seeking God's guidance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:46 acknowledges rumors and violence but implies believers should not faint or fear, trusting God's plan. The passage encourages faith and courage rather than fear.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 51 describes Babylon as a _____ cup in the LORD's hand that made all the earth drunken.
options: golden
bitter
empty
forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: golden
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:7 calls Babylon a 'golden cup' in the LORD's hand, illustrating how God used Babylon's influence over the nations, causing them to become intoxicated with her wine.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51 teach about the importance of prayer and personal devotion when facing overwhelming opposition?
options: Trust in God’s power and righteousness, proclaim His work, and seek His deliverance through faith.
Rely on human wisdom alone to overcome difficulties.
Ignore God and focus on self-help strategies.
Give up on prayer when challenges seem too great.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s power and righteousness, proclaim His work, and seek His deliverance through faith.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:10 and 15 emphasize declaring God's work and recognizing His power and wisdom, encouraging believers to depend on God in prayer and devotion during trials.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 51.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Jeremiah 51 to describe Babylon's influence on the nations?
options: A golden cup that made all the earth drunken
A roaring lion that devours its prey
A mighty mountain that cannot be moved
A burning fire that consumes everything
questions.correctAnswer: A golden cup that made all the earth drunken
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:7 describes Babylon as "a golden cup in the LORD'S hand, that made all the earth drunken," illustrating its intoxicating influence over the nations.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 51, who has the LORD raised up against Babylon to execute His vengeance?
options: The kings of the Medes
The Egyptians
The Greeks
The Romans
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of the Medes
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:11 states that the LORD has raised up the spirit of the kings of the Medes against Babylon to destroy it, emphasizing the historical role of the Medes in Babylon's downfall.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase "the vengeance of his temple" in Jeremiah 51:11?
options: It highlights God's defense of His sanctuary against Babylon's defilement
It refers to the temple in Babylon being destroyed
It symbolizes a new temple to be built after Babylon’s fall
It is a reference to the temple in Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God's defense of His sanctuary against Babylon's defilement
questions.explanation: The phrase indicates that God's action against Babylon is motivated by vengeance for the temple, i.e., His holy place defiled or threatened by Babylon, as seen in Jeremiah 51:11.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 51 describes Babylon as a "destroying ______" raised up by the LORD.
options: wind
lion
fire
flood
questions.correctAnswer: wind
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:1 uses the metaphor of a "destroying wind" to describe the judgment God will bring against Babylon.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51, what will happen to the walls and gates of Babylon?
options: The broad walls shall be utterly broken and the high gates burned with fire
They shall be rebuilt stronger than before
They will remain intact as a testimony
They will be taken as spoils by the Medes
questions.correctAnswer: The broad walls shall be utterly broken and the high gates burned with fire
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:58 prophesies the destruction of Babylon’s defenses, emphasizing total ruin with broken walls and gates burned by fire.

questions.question: What is the deeper theological implication of calling Israel "the rod of his inheritance" in Jeremiah 51:19?
options: Israel is God's chosen instrument for His covenant promises
Israel is a conquered nation under Babylonian rule
Israel is destined to be destroyed with Babylon
Israel is a symbol of worldly power
questions.correctAnswer: Israel is God's chosen instrument for His covenant promises
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:19 highlights Israel as the special possession and instrument of God, the 'rod of his inheritance,' underscoring covenantal faithfulness and divine purpose.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 51 describes the fall of Babylon as sudden and complete, with no hope for healing.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:8-9 portrays Babylon's fall as sudden and irreparable, stating that healing is not possible and her judgment reaches unto heaven.

questions.question: Which of the following best illustrates the literary device used in Jeremiah 51:40 where Babylon’s destruction is compared to lambs to the slaughter?
options: Simile
Metaphor
Hyperbole
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:40 uses a simile, comparing Babylon’s downfall to lambs led to slaughter, employing 'like' to highlight vulnerability and inevitability.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 51:44, what is the significance of the judgment upon Bel in Babylon?
options: It signifies the downfall of Babylon's chief deity and false religion
It indicates the restoration of Babylon's gods
It refers to a Babylonian king named Bel
It symbolizes the building of a new temple
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies the downfall of Babylon's chief deity and false religion
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:44 pronounces judgment on Bel, Babylon’s main god, symbolizing the collapse of its idolatry and religious power.

questions.question: What is the historical role of Seraiah in relation to Jeremiah's prophecy as described in Jeremiah 51:59-64?
options: He was commanded to read the prophecy in Babylon and cast the book into the Euphrates
He led the army to destroy Babylon
He was the king of Babylon
He built the walls of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: He was commanded to read the prophecy in Babylon and cast the book into the Euphrates
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:59-64 narrates that Jeremiah instructed Seraiah to publicly read the prophecy in Babylon and then throw the book into the Euphrates, symbolizing Babylon’s sinking.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51:15-16 emphasize God's sovereignty over creation in the context of Babylon's judgment?
options: By describing God's power in creating the earth, heavens, and controlling natural forces
By recounting Babylon's military might
By listing Babylon's treasures
By mentioning the Medes' armies
questions.correctAnswer: By describing God's power in creating the earth, heavens, and controlling natural forces
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 highlight God's creative and sustaining power, reinforcing His authority to bring judgment on Babylon as Creator and Ruler.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 51:24 says the LORD will render unto Babylon "all their evil that they have done in ________."
options: Zion
Jerusalem
Egypt
Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: Zion
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:24 declares that Babylon will receive recompense for its evil acts committed in Zion, God's holy city.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase "the portion of Jacob is not like them" in Jeremiah 51:19?
options: It contrasts Israel's unique relationship with God to the futility of idols
It refers to Jacob’s inheritance of land
It praises Babylon’s gods
It describes Jacob’s descendants as idolaters
questions.correctAnswer: It contrasts Israel's unique relationship with God to the futility of idols
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:19 contrasts Israel, formed and protected by God, with the vanity and falsehood of idols mentioned earlier in the chapter.

questions.question: What literary structure is evident in the series of verses Jeremiah 51:20-23, where multiple groups are listed as broken by God’s instrument?
options: Parallelism
Chiasm
Allegory
Parable
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Verses 20-23 utilize parallelism, repetitively listing groups broken by God’s instrument to emphasize comprehensive judgment.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:6, what are the people urged to do to avoid being caught in Babylon’s iniquity?
options: Flee out of the midst of Babylon and deliver their souls
Build stronger walls around Babylon
Join Babylon's armies
Offer sacrifices to Babylon's gods
questions.correctAnswer: Flee out of the midst of Babylon and deliver their souls
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:6 commands the people to escape Babylon so they won’t be destroyed with her in divine judgment.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 51 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 51 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51, what is the LORD's declared purpose in raising up a destroying wind against Babylon?
options: To punish Babylon for its sins and bring divine vengeance
To bless Babylon with peace and prosperity
To establish Babylon as a center of worship
To make Babylon a refuge for the oppressed
questions.correctAnswer: To punish Babylon for its sins and bring divine vengeance
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:1-6 clearly shows God raising a destroying wind against Babylon as an act of vengeance due to her sins and iniquities. This fits with broader biblical themes where God's judgment comes upon nations for their rebellion (cf. Isaiah 13:17-19; Ezekiel 26:7-14; Revelation 18).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:5 affirm about Israel and Judah despite their sinfulness?
options: They have not been forsaken by God
They are completely rejected by God
They will be destroyed without hope
They will become like Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: They have not been forsaken by God
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that Israel and Judah have not been forsaken by the LORD of hosts despite their sin, highlighting God's faithfulness and covenantal mercy (cf. Deuteronomy 7:9; Isaiah 54:7-8; Romans 11:1-2).

questions.question: Jeremiah 51 describes Babylon as a 'golden cup' in the LORD's hand. What does this metaphor signify?
options: Babylon caused all the earth to become drunk and mad
Babylon was a source of healing for the nations
Babylon was a vessel of God's blessing
Babylon was a symbol of wisdom and justice
questions.correctAnswer: Babylon caused all the earth to become drunk and mad
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 51:7 calls Babylon a golden cup that made all the earth drunken, referring to its intoxicating influence leading to madness and judgment (cf. Revelation 17:2-4; Isaiah 51:17; Habakkuk 2:15-16).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:11 say about the spirit God has raised up against Babylon?
options: The spirit of the kings of the Medes to destroy Babylon
The spirit of Babylon's allies to protect her
The spirit of peace to reconcile nations
The spirit of Israel to rebuild Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit of the kings of the Medes to destroy Babylon
questions.explanation: Verse 11 highlights God's sovereign orchestration of history by raising the Medes against Babylon, demonstrating divine judgment through nations (cf. Isaiah 13:17; Daniel 5; Revelation 16:12).

questions.question: How is God described as creating and sustaining the world in Jeremiah 51:15-16?
options: By His power, wisdom, and understanding
By chance and natural forces
Through the work of angels
By the will of the nations
questions.correctAnswer: By His power, wisdom, and understanding
questions.explanation: These verses affirm God's attributes as Creator, Wisdom, and Sovereign Sustainer, consistent with biblical teaching (cf. Genesis 1:1; Psalm 104:24; Proverbs 3:19; Colossians 1:16-17).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:17 say about the knowledge of man in relation to idols?
options: Man is brutish and founders are confounded by graven images
Man is wise and creates true gods
Man's knowledge leads him to worship the true God
Man is enlightened by idols
questions.correctAnswer: Man is brutish and founders are confounded by graven images
questions.explanation: Verse 17 condemns idolatry and highlights human folly in worshiping lifeless images, echoing themes from Exodus 20:3-5, Psalm 115:4-8, and Isaiah 44:9-20.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 51:20-23, what metaphor does God use to describe His instrument of judgment against nations?
options: Battle axe and weapons of war
A peaceful dove
A shepherd's staff
A healing balm
questions.correctAnswer: Battle axe and weapons of war
questions.explanation: God calls Babylon His battle axe and weapons of war used to break nations, symbolizing the use of instruments for executing His judgment (cf. Isaiah 10:5-6; Jeremiah 25:9; Revelation 19:15).

questions.question: What is God's promise concerning the stones of Babylon according to Jeremiah 51:26?
options: No stone will be taken for a corner or foundation; Babylon will be desolate forever
Stones will be used to rebuild Babylon
Stones will be hidden and preserved
Stones will become precious treasures
questions.correctAnswer: No stone will be taken for a corner or foundation; Babylon will be desolate forever
questions.explanation: Verse 26 prophesies complete and permanent desolation, emphasizing total destruction and inability to rebuild, consistent with Ezekiel 26:4-5 and Revelation 18:21.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:34 reveal about Nebuchadrezzar's treatment of the prophet?
options: He devoured, crushed, and swallowed him up like a dragon
He protected and honored him
He ignored him
He sent him on a mission
questions.correctAnswer: He devoured, crushed, and swallowed him up like a dragon
questions.explanation: This verse uses vivid imagery to describe the suffering inflicted by Babylon's king, symbolizing oppression and injustice (cf. Psalm 22:14-15; Isaiah 51:9).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 51:45 counsel God's people in relation to Babylon's impending judgment?
options: To go out of Babylon and deliver every man his soul
To defend Babylon at all costs
To remain silent and wait
To join Babylon in its rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: To go out of Babylon and deliver every man his soul
questions.explanation: Verse 45 exhorts the faithful to separate themselves from Babylon to avoid God's fierce anger, echoing calls for holiness and separation found in 2 Corinthians 6:17 and Revelation 18:4.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 51:57, what will happen to Babylon's princes, wise men, captains, rulers, and mighty men?
options: They will be made drunk and sleep a perpetual sleep
They will conquer their enemies
They will be exalted by God
They will flee to other lands
questions.correctAnswer: They will be made drunk and sleep a perpetual sleep
questions.explanation: This imagery symbolizes total defeat and incapacitation of Babylon's leadership, reflecting God's judgment (cf. Isaiah 29:9-10; Revelation 17:2; Nahum 1:10).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 51:54 say is the reason for the great destruction coming from Babylon?
options: Because the LORD has spoiled Babylon and destroyed its great voice
Because Babylon repented and sought mercy
Because Babylon became righteous
Because Babylon formed alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD has spoiled Babylon and destroyed its great voice
questions.explanation: Verse 54 attributes the destruction directly to God's action, emphasizing divine sovereignty in judgment (cf. Isaiah 13:19; Ezekiel 26:21; Revelation 18:6).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 51:48, what cosmic response is predicted when Babylon is judged?
options: Heaven, earth, and all therein shall sing for Babylon
The sun will be darkened
The stars will fall from heaven
The seas will dry up
questions.correctAnswer: Heaven, earth, and all therein shall sing for Babylon
questions.explanation: Verse 48 depicts creation rejoicing over God's justice, aligning with biblical motifs of cosmic praise for God's acts (cf. Psalm 96:11-13; Isaiah 44:23; Revelation 5:13).

questions.question: What is the significance of binding a stone to the book and casting it into the Euphrates as commanded in Jeremiah 51:63-64?
options: It symbolizes Babylon sinking and never rising again
It is a ritual to bless Babylon
It represents Babylon's blessing of Israel
It is a sign of Babylon's future prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes Babylon sinking and never rising again
questions.explanation: This prophetic action in verses 63-64 symbolically enacts Babylon's final downfall, emphasizing the certainty of God's judgment (cf. Ezekiel 12:3-6; Jeremiah 25:12).

questions.question: What is the nature of the vengeance God declares against Babylon in Jeremiah 51:24?
options: Rendering to Babylon and Chaldea all their evil done to Zion
Blessing Babylon with peace
Ignoring Babylon's sins
Forgiving Babylon unconditionally
questions.correctAnswer: Rendering to Babylon and Chaldea all their evil done to Zion
questions.explanation: Verse 24 shows God's justice as retributive, holding Babylon accountable for their wrongs against His people, consistent with biblical justice (cf. Deuteronomy 32:35; Romans 12:19; Revelation 6:10).
